item.title: No More Paper Towels for Some UNHQ Restrooms in Latest Austerity Step
item.description: The United Nations will no longer provide paper towels in restrooms servicing office spaces in its headquarters in New York City and has encouraged more use of the electric hand-dryers installed in these areas. The step, announced on Dec. 10 in a UN-systemwide email, is the latest in a series of small and big ... Read more

item.title: Exclusive: Former Iraqi president picked to lead UN Refugee Agency
item.description: Barham Salih's appointment breaks the tradition of European leadership of the world's premier refugee outfit.

item.title: Can the US-Africa trade program AGOA be resurrected?
item.description: AGOA expired Sept. 30, but the House Ways and Means Committee approved a three-year extension on Wednesday. The bill still faces some hurdles, but there is hope for the trade program that has garnered bipartisan support.

item.title: The top global development employers in Haiti in 2025
item.description: Devex takes a look at the top global development employers in Haiti, based on who has been hiring in 2025.

item.title: Ambitious climate pledges mean little without systems to follow through
item.description: Opinion: Brazil called COP30 the implementation summit. But delivery on climate action is carried out beyond COP, by local governments, ministries, and community groups.

item.title: In Taliban-Ruled Afghanistan, a Young Woman Works in Disguise to Feed Her Family
item.description: The author is an Afghanistan-based female journalist, trained with Finnish support before the Taliban take-over. Her identity is withheld for security reasons

item.title: ‘Once Conversations about Democracy and Equality Begin, They Are Very Hard to Silence’
item.description: CIVICUS discusses restrictions on civic space in Thailand and the detention of activist and human rights lawyer Arnon Nampa with Akarachai Chaimaneekarakate, Advocacy Lead at Thai Lawyers for Human Rights (TLHR). Thai authorities are using the country’s draconian lèse-majesté law, which bans criticism of the monarchy, to criminalise dissent and shut down debates about […]

item.title: Devex CheckUp: The Trump insider who will lead Malaria No More in 2026
item.description: A Trump insider has been picked to lead Malaria No More starting in January. Plus, Gates Foundation sounds the alarm about the link between health funding cuts and child deaths, and Fiji sees massive rise in HIV cases.

item.title: Africa has made bold health commitments. Now it must finance them
item.description: Opinion: Across Africa, the belief in universal health care is not new, and neither are the declarations, compacts and strategies that promise to deliver it. But as the proverb says, “A chattering bird builds no nest.”

item.title: Our work is redefining cancer care in Africa. Now we need global partners
item.description: Opinion: Our clinical research in Nairobi, and alliances with pan-African cancer treatment centers is delivering positive results to patients on the continent.

item.title: Devex Newswire: The agencies and people still fighting Trump’s aid shutdown
item.description: Where do the legal battles for humanitarian aid stand in U.S. courts? Plus, the former USAID staffer who created a network of security experts after he was fired earlier this year, and what’s happening at UNEA-7.

item.title: Turning commitments into action: Financing a healthier future after HLM4
item.description: Opinion: HLM4 and the resulting political declaration must be a turning point, catalyzing sustained financing and collaboration to transform political commitments on NCDs and mental health into real action.

item.title: Venezuela’s National Guard linked to killings, torture and repression, UN probe finds
item.description: Venezuela’s Bolivarian National Guard (GNB) has been implicated in a decade-long pattern of killings, arbitrary detentions, torture and sexual violence targeting protesters and opponents of President Nicolás Maduro, according to a new report from UN-appointed investigators on Thursday.

item.title: Risks mount for pregnant women in Ukraine
item.description: Pregnant women took shelter in a bunkerised maternity unit in the Ukrainian city of Kherson last week, after a hospital was struck just 1.5 km from the frontline.

item.title: Gaza’s maternal and newborn health system ‘decimated’, UN warns
item.description: Gaza’s health system for mothers and newborns has been “decimated”, the UN said on Thursday, with Israeli attacks destroying almost all hospitals, cutting off medical supplies and driving sharp rises in maternal deaths, miscarriages and newborn fatalities amid mass displacement and hunger.

item.title: WHO expert group reaffirms no link between vaccines and autism
item.description: A World Health Organization (WHO) expert committee has again confirmed that there is no causal link between vaccines and autism spectrum disorders (ASD), following a new review of global scientific evidence.

item.title: UN warns of ‘regional conflagration’ as DR Congo violence uproots 500,000
item.description: More than half a million people have now been uprooted by escalating violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) the UN said on Thursday, warning that the M23 rebel offensive is driving a rapidly worsening humanitarian emergency.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa: WFP calls for greater investment in preparedness, building resilience
item.description: More than a month after Hurricane Melissa slammed the Caribbean, devastated communities still require assistance, the regional director for the World Food Programme (WFP) told journalists at UN Headquarters on Thursday.

item.title: CIVICUS 2025 Report Reveals Widespread Attacks on Civic Freedoms Worldwide
item.description: Over the course of 2025, global civic space conditions have deteriorated sharply, with most countries experiencing some degree of obstructed civil liberties.
